Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Council for Big Data, Ethics, and Society

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Big data are changing the ways in which individuals are tracked and the corresponding ways in which science must respond. Data uses run the gamut from public health modeling to personalization of online content to potentially discriminatory practices. Big data involve not just using new tools to get better answers but also new social, cultural and ethical issues. This award establishes a model for dealing with the ethical, social and legal impacts of big data projects from their outset, with an eye to developing next generation protocols to cover these kinds of impacts. A multidisciplinary council will be established to engage with and complement discussions already underway in mathematics, the sciences, engineering, and computer science. The goal of the Council will be to address issues such as security, privacy, equality, and access in order to help guard against the repetition of earlier mistakes and inadequate preparation. Through public commentary, events, white papers, and direct engagement with data analytics projects, the Council will develop frameworks to help researchers, practitioners, and the public understand the social, ethical, legal, and policy issues that underpin big data phenomena.

Functionally, the goal will be to help guard against the repetition of known mistakes and inadequate preparation by working across domains and disciplines involved in big data projects. In the process, those working on this project will develop new and powerful paradigms for identifying and understanding leading edge social, political, ethical, and legal issues. Both the research outputs and the coordinated network will help inform the design of scientific projects. Furthermore, the public-oriented nature and accessible outputs of this project will provide input for public discussions surrounding the big data phenomena by engaging with journalists, educators, and public policy makers. This project will create an influential community of thought leaders that can help shape the understanding of the complexities of the big data and also provide engagement for young scientists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Council for Big Data, Ethics, and Society was started in 2014 to provide critical social and cultural perspectives on big data initiatives. The Council brought together researchers from diverse disciplines — from anthropology and computer science to astronomy and law to economics and philosophy — to address issues such as security, privacy, equality, and access in order to help guard against the repetition of known mistakes and inadequate preparation. Through public commentary, events, white papers, and direct engagement with data analytics projects, the Council developed frameworks to help researchers, practitioners, and the public understand the social, ethical, legal, and policy issues that underpin the big data phenomenon. Through meetings and conference calls over a two-year period, members discussed and produced reports about data ethics interventions, tradeoffs, and emerging challenges. They also produced an online collection of original and curated literature and responded to public and policy issues that arose. The Council was directed by danah boyd, Geoffrey Bowker, Kate Crawford, and Helen Nissenbaum, and hosted by Data & Society Research Institute.

The Council’s outputs have focused on the concrete consequences of the disjunction between big data research methods and existing research ethics resources, including policy, pedagogy, and cultural and institutional manifestations. Council reports have examined big data projects supported by the National Science Foundation; the history of ethical codes from mid-20th century; debates about personal genomics, the use of student data for personalized learning, and social media algorithms; the history of data management plans as a tool for integrating ethics principles; an examination of data ethics courses and modules in fields such as statistics, business, computer science, and journalism; the application of human subjects protections from the social sciences to big data analytics; and potential impacts of the recently proposed changes to the Common Rule by the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services. Additionally, a collaborative discussion with industry representatives in the Council’s final meeting provided a unique opportunity for mutual ideas exchange and knowledge building between academia and industry.

A case study series was created through a public call for submissions to illustrate distinct ethical challenges. For example, in “No Encore for Encore: Ethical questions for web-based censorship measurement,” Council member Arvind Narayanan and co-author Bendert Zevenbergen explored the ethical implications of using research methods that innocuously alter the behavior of subjects’ computers without their knowledge or consent. Additional case studies explored scenarios in which a data scientist subverted engineering best practices in pursuit of social justice aims, and a pair of researchers contemplated the utilization of hacked datasets that had been released in public forums. The Council’s call for case studies was coupled with a network expansion, which drew from nominations to build a community of researchers and thinkers with a scholarly interest in the social, technical, legal, and ethical issues raised by the “big data” phenomenon.

Through a final white paper, the Council discussed the ways that traditional structures for science and engineering research ethics are not equipped to handle big data research methods; the grey areas in human subjects protections, such as whether computer science research or data science should be considered human subjects research in the absence of a direct intervention, and the potential for group or societal harms not addressed by individual protections; the emergence of informal networks, such as data clinics, to support researchers in ethical decision-making; the limitations of informed consent to account for potential data uses after a research study has ended; and ethical review processes in the corporate sector, where IRB requirements for federally funded research do not apply. The white paper provides significant recommendations for both policy changes and future areas of research for the data ethics community to pursue.

Results of the Council’s work consist of research products, public resources, and engagement with a variety of stakeholders. The Council’s written reports and in-person discussions have facilitated the growth of nuanced ethical thinking about big data collection, analysis, and publishing, and engaged people from a wide array of disciplines to showcase where differences lie. The reports, case studies, and white paper – combined with a curated literature review containing resources for teaching data ethics – provide frameworks for researchers, scholars, and educators to approach technical work with ethical principles in mind. In addition, members of the Council have given hundreds of talks to academic associations, government agencies, technology companies, civil society, and in public venues, as well as writing op-eds and responding to emergent issues through radio and TV interviews and by working with journalists. Overall, the Council’s work has done much to facilitate and structure the growth of scholarly research and public discourse about the social, ethical, and legal dynamics of the big data phenomenon.

The Council’s reports and resources can be found on the website below: http://bdes.datasociety.net/.
